author: jgm
content:
The chain probably needs to have some sort of recognised infancy, where there is some sort of compensation for such issues.  But it quickly becomes very difficult to argue about which products are "in" and which are "out" of the compensated entities, given the cost of audits and the pace of change of the software.

The best answer is to insulate the components from each other, so that (for example) a bug in a beacon node _cannot_ create a slashable offence because it's the signer that protects against that.  This would allow a reduction in the surface that needs to be protected against, and more chance of being able to provide some sort of limited set of guarantees.

author: jgm
content:
Trouble with that is that it's quite possible for the results to be different without being wrong.  Client A may be behind client B in an absolute sense, but if the majority of nodes are in client A's position then that's where the vote weight goes.

The actual attack surface for phase 0 is pretty small, in terms of not being slashed.  There are a few simple rules that the signer has to follow.

A lot of issues will come from the operational side: users running the same validator keys on two nodes at the same time, not failing over properly, exposing their keys, _etc._  Not something that can be easily protected against, but it won't make the losses any less painful.

content: hey, so, i was looking at the beacon chain explorer (at beaconcha.in), and I noticed that there are epochs that are marked as not finalized that have later epochs that are marked as finalized (presumably finalized checkpoints).  one example would be epoch 2240.  there are also some epochs during the low participation portion of the launch of the medalla testnet (for example, epoch 3000 where participation was 2%) and yet, this is marked as finalized.  is there some discrepancy/errors in how the beacon chain explorer marks epochs as finalized?  or am i misunderstanding something about the beacon chain explorer?

author: djrtwo
content:
this seems like a peculiarity of the explorer and/or the API it is requesting from

When epoch X is directly finalized, all epochs prior to it in the chain are then considered "finalized" even if say `X-2` wasn't directly finalized. 
That said, the block epxlorer could choose to note that subtlety in a few different ways. Not sure what beaconcha.in is doing exactly
